title: Hate crimes jump by 10% in one year across England and Wales
text:
The Home Office said there were spikes in hate crimes being reported as a result of the EU referendum (Picture: WENN)

The number of hate crimes recorded in England and Wales in 2018/19 soared by more than 10 per cent on the previous year, new official figures show.

Of the 103,379 offences recorded by police this year, 76 per cent were race hate crimes.

The number of hate crimes has more than doubled since 2012/13, when 42,255 were recorded, data from the Home Office showed.

Transgender identity hate crimes increased by 37 per cent to 2,333, homophobic attacks rose 25 per cent to 14,491 and disability hate crimes increased by 14 per cent to 8,256, in a year.

Offences motivated by religion rose by 9 per cent to 8,336, the figures revealed.

In September, police released footage of a woman racially abusing an Indian bus passenger, in Brentford, West London (Picture: News Dog Media)

In June, Melania Geymonat and her girlfriend Chris were beaten up on a bus in a homophobic attack (Picture: Sam Webb)

The Home Office report put an ‘ongoing rise’ in hate crimes in part down to improvements in the way crimes are recorded.

But it added there were spikes in reported crimes after events such as the EU referendum in 2016 and UK terrorist attacks in 2017.

The report said: ‘Part of the increase over the last year may reflect a real rise in hate crimes recorded by the police.’

More than half of the hate crimes recorded were for public order offences which usually refer to the use of or threat of violence or harassment towards someone else, in a public place.

A third involved violence and five per cent were recorded as criminal damage and arson.

John Keogh was fined £600 in July for a racist outburst at a betting shop, telling a black woman ‘when Brexit comes you will be gone’ (Picture: PA)

Around 12 per cent of hate crime offences were estimated to have more than one motivation, with the majority of these being both race and religion.

Hate crimes are defined as those perceived to be motivated by hostility or prejudice of a characteristic.

Five strands are monitored nationally: race or ethnicity; religion or beliefs; sexual orientation; disability; and transgender identity.

Some police forces log other types of hostility under hate crime, including reports of misogyny and incidents where victims were targeted because of their age or membership of an ‘alternative sub-culture’, such as goths.
